title: How to Grow Acorn Squash

steps.headline: Ensure you have at least a three and a half month growing season in full sun.
steps.description: Acorn squash takes two and a half to three and a half months to mature, and, like most types of winter squash, can’t be picked before they are ripe. Extra acorn squash seeds can be saved for six years.

steps.headline: Purchase a packet of acorn squash seeds at your local gardening supply store.
steps.description: If you’d rather not plant your own seeds, you can wait until spring to find seedlings and starts at your farmer’s market or garden center.

steps.headline: Start seeds inside three to four weeks before you expect the last frost of the season.
steps.description: Check your state’s almanac to see when that will be. If you have a longer growing season, start your seeds outdoors about two weeks after the first frost.

steps.headline: Cover the seeds in a warm damp paper towel for a few hours, while you prepare your soil.
Plant six seeds in three-inch (7.6 cm) pots.
steps.description: Seedling trays are not generally big enough for squash seedlings. Fill the pots with seed mix and sprinkle with warm water before planting each seed one inch (2.5 cm) deep.

steps.headline: Place the seeds in a sunny window that you can supplement with fluorescent light.
steps.description: Cover the pot with plastic wrap for the first few days to improve germination. Generally, the seeds sprout within 5 to 12 days.

steps.headline: Thin the seeds to three per pot when they start to crowd.
steps.description: They should be ready to transplant into your garden soon.

steps.headline: Prepare your beds.
steps.description: You need at least a three-foot (0.9 m) plot in all direction to grow winter squash without overshadowing other vegetables. Your bed should be in full sunlight. If you don’t have three feet (0.9 m) to spare, build a trellis or use a fence to grow the squash vertically. They can be separated two feet (0.6 m) apart and trained to grow up the support system.

steps.headline: Amend your soil with compost in the winter, if possible.
steps.description: Aim for a pH content between 5.8 and 6.8 for best results.

steps.headline: Aim to plant your seedlings when the soil has warmed to approximately 70 degrees Fahrenheit (21 Celsius).
Loosen the soil to a depth of at least 12 inches (30.5 cm).
Place mulch around your squash for the first few weeks if you have a weed problem.
steps.description: After the broad leaves start to form, you should weed by hand regularly. The large leaves will shade out some weeds.

steps.headline: Water your squash mounds when the soil begins to dry out.
steps.description: Let it soak for a few minutes to reach the whole root system. Water below the leaves to avoid powdery mildew and scab.

steps.headline: Look out for squash vine borers that leave “sawdust.” You can remove them by hand.
steps.description: Cover your plants with netting cheesecloth while they are young, if you have a problem with cucumber beetles.

steps.headline: Test the acorn squash individually after two to three months.
steps.description: They will have a dark green shell when they are nearing maturity. When the skin is strong enough to resist being pierced by your fingernail, they are ready to pick.

steps.headline: Cut the squash from the stem, leaving approximately one inch (2.5 cm) of stem on the squash.
steps.description: Use a sharp pair of kitchen or garden shears.

steps.headline: Rinse and dry the surface.
steps.description: Find a cool, dry and dark place to store your squash.

steps.headline: Place them side by side rather than stacking them.
steps.description: If stored in a less than optimal area, they can last for two to three weeks. If stored in a cellar, they can last several months.

text:
Starting Squash Seedlings Ensure you have at least a three and a half month growing season in full sun. Acorn squash takes two and a half to three and a half months to mature, and, like most types of winter squash, can’t be picked before they are ripe. Extra acorn squash seeds can be saved for six years. Purchase a packet of acorn squash seeds at your local gardening supply store. If you’d rather not plant your own seeds, you can wait until spring to find seedlings and starts at your farmer’s market or garden center. Start seeds inside three to four weeks before you expect the last frost of the season. Check your state’s almanac to see when that will be. If you have a longer growing season, start your seeds outdoors about two weeks after the first frost. Cover the seeds in a warm damp paper towel for a few hours, while you prepare your soil. Plant six seeds in three-inch (7.6 cm) pots. Seedling trays are not generally big enough for squash seedlings. Fill the pots with seed mix and sprinkle with warm water before planting each seed one inch (2.5 cm) deep. Place the seeds in a sunny window that you can supplement with fluorescent light. Cover the pot with plastic wrap for the first few days to improve germination. Generally, the seeds sprout within 5 to 12 days. Thin the seeds to three per pot when they start to crowd. They should be ready to transplant into your garden soon. Planting Acorn Squash Prepare your beds. You need at least a three-foot (0.9 m) plot in all direction to grow winter squash without overshadowing other vegetables. Your bed should be in full sunlight. If you don’t have three feet (0.9 m) to spare, build a trellis or use a fence to grow the squash vertically. They can be separated two feet (0.6 m) apart and trained to grow up the support system. Amend your soil with compost in the winter, if possible. Aim for a pH content between 5.8 and 6.8 for best results. Aim to plant your seedlings when the soil has warmed to approximately 70 degrees Fahrenheit (21 Celsius). Loosen the soil to a depth of at least 12 inches (30.5 cm). Then, plant in three-foot (0.9 m) mounds with approximately three seedlings per mound. Planting atop a mound ensures that the roots will not rot, since squash require a lot of watering. If you are planting seeds directly into the garden, plant them in a mound with six seeds per mound. Thin to three plants after germination. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Acorn squash that are planted near a fence or trellis will not need to be mounded. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Grow-Acorn-Squash-Step-11Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":334,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":552.2527472527472,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Growing Acorn Squash Place mulch around your squash for the first few weeks if you have a weed problem. After the broad leaves start to form, you should weed by hand regularly. The large leaves will shade out some weeds. Water your squash mounds when the soil begins to dry out. Let it soak for a few minutes to reach the whole root system. Water below the leaves to avoid powdery mildew and scab. Look out for squash vine borers that leave “sawdust.” You can remove them by hand. Cover your plants with netting cheesecloth while they are young, if you have a problem with cucumber beetles. Harvesting Acorn Squash Test the acorn squash individually after two to three months. They will have a dark green shell when they are nearing maturity. When the skin is strong enough to resist being pierced by your fingernail, they are ready to pick. Cut the squash from the stem, leaving approximately one inch (2.5 cm) of stem on the squash. Use a sharp pair of kitchen or garden shears. Rinse and dry the surface. Find a cool, dry and dark place to store your squash. Place them side by side rather than stacking them. If stored in a less than optimal area, they can last for two to three weeks. If stored in a cellar, they can last several months.
sentences: Starting Squash Seedlings Ensure you have at least a three and a half month growing season in full sun.
Acorn squash takes two and a half to three and a half months to mature, and, like most types of winter squash, can’t be picked before they are ripe.
Extra acorn squash seeds can be saved for six years.
Purchase a packet of acorn squash seeds at your local gardening supply store.
If you’d rather not plant your own seeds, you can wait until spring to find seedlings and starts at your farmer’s market or garden center.
Start seeds inside three to four weeks before you expect the last frost of the season.
Check your state’s almanac to see when that will be.
If you have a longer growing season, start your seeds outdoors about two weeks after the first frost.
Cover the seeds in a warm damp paper towel for a few hours, while you prepare your soil.
Plant six seeds in three-inch (7.6 cm) pots.
Seedling trays are not generally big enough for squash seedlings.
Fill the pots with seed mix and sprinkle with warm water before planting each seed one inch (2.5 cm) deep.
Place the seeds in a sunny window that you can supplement with fluorescent light.
Cover the pot with plastic wrap for the first few days to improve germination.
Generally, the seeds sprout within 5 to 12 days.
Thin the seeds to three per pot when they start to crowd.
They should be ready to transplant into your garden soon.
Planting Acorn Squash Prepare your beds.
You need at least a three-foot (0.9 m) plot in all direction to grow winter squash without overshadowing other vegetables.
Your bed should be in full sunlight.
If you don’t have three feet (0.9 m) to spare, build a trellis or use a fence to grow the squash vertically.
They can be separated two feet (0.6 m) apart and trained to grow up the support system.
Amend your soil with compost in the winter, if possible.
Aim for a pH content between 5.8 and 6.8 for best results.
Aim to plant your seedlings when the soil has warmed to approximately 70 degrees Fahrenheit (21 Celsius).
Loosen the soil to a depth of at least 12 inches (30.5 cm).
Then, plant in three-foot (0.9 m) mounds with approximately three seedlings per mound.
Planting atop a mound ensures that the roots will not rot, since squash require a lot of watering.
If you are planting seeds directly into the garden, plant them in a mound with six seeds per mound.
Thin to three plants after germination.

\n<\/p><\/div>"} Growing Acorn Squash Place mulch around your squash for the first few weeks if you have a weed problem.
After the broad leaves start to form, you should weed by hand regularly.
The large leaves will shade out some weeds.
Water your squash mounds when the soil begins to dry out.
Let it soak for a few minutes to reach the whole root system.
Water below the leaves to avoid powdery mildew and scab.
Look out for squash vine borers that leave “sawdust.” You can remove them by hand.
Cover your plants with netting cheesecloth while they are young, if you have a problem with cucumber beetles.
Harvesting Acorn Squash Test the acorn squash individually after two to three months.
They will have a dark green shell when they are nearing maturity.
When the skin is strong enough to resist being pierced by your fingernail, they are ready to pick.
Cut the squash from the stem, leaving approximately one inch (2.5 cm) of stem on the squash.
Use a sharp pair of kitchen or garden shears.
Rinse and dry the surface.
Find a cool, dry and dark place to store your squash.
Place them side by side rather than stacking them.
If stored in a less than optimal area, they can last for two to three weeks.
If stored in a cellar, they can last several months.
